articles.headline: Gen IV Power Plant Approved for Construction
articles.content:
This is amazing. OMG. Why don't we have more news like this. The future is going to be great. Just you wait and see.

articles.headline: Safe and Plentiful, Don't you know it? Bah
articles.byline: Zanzibar, Nuclear Hero, Badoongy face, Blah
articles.content: Nuclear power is safe for the climate and we have lots of fuel. Now comes the real trick. Bordon.

courses.title: Nuclear Physics Fundamentals
courses.synopsis: Explores the fundamental concepts of nuclear science. Isotopes. Radioactive decay. Neutrons. Chain reactions.

courses.title: Generation IV Nuclear Power
courses.synopsis: Explains the goals of generation IV nuclear power. Provides an overview of reactor types and safety measures.

courses.title: Learning from Nuclear Accidents
courses.synopsis: Nuclear energy has a nasty reputation. Some of it is earned due to accidents and careless behavior. This course takes a look at what has gone wrong so far and what we have learned from the experience.

lessons.title: The Right Dose for the Job
Types of Gen IV Nuclear Reactors
They Can Almost Fit in Your Pocket (SMRs)

contentBlocks.content: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

When it comes to liquid, it's pretty common to think of water. However, many materials melt when things get hot enough. Salt is one such material. Let's learn about how molten salt can be used in a nuclear reactor.

The melting point of salt is perfect for handling the heat of a nuclear reaction.The vapor point is also much higher than a nuclear react will get, even if things get a little overheated. Also, as we know, when salt cools it turns into a solid.

contentBlocks.caption: Schematic for molten salt reactor
contentBlocks.explanation: This is a schematic of a molten salt reactor. On the left, you can see where the heat is generated. On the right, you see where electricity is generated. All of the pipes are there to move liquid salt and cooling water. Isn't that interesting?

contentBlocks.title: How a molten salt reactor works
contentBlocks.caption: Video about molten salt reactors

contentBlocks.content: How does an MSR reactor keep the salt from getting too cool. And how does the salt reliquify once it does, say when the reactor is starting up? These are engineering challenges.
